item.title: How I got here
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: Today I resigned. I was worried my bosses were going to be furious -we are a small/medium company and a close team- but to my relief they were very understanding and supportive. A new chapter starts; well, it does in three months, when the Makers Academy precourse begins. When I moved to the UK -about six years ago-, I had a dream: to become a sound engineer and work at Abbey Road studios. The best way to achieve that goal is doing the course I did -Sound Engineering (Tonmeister) in Guildford- as a large proportion of the studio's staff are graduates from this course. I loved it; we learned about the physics of sound, music theory, the electronics behind microphones/speakers, recording/mixing mastering techniques. A number of exams consisted in recording/producing a band and then submitting the finished product -this was heaven! I loved it. However, with time I realised something: what I was really good at is making everything in the studio fit together and work well. I really enjoy thinking about how the whole system works and troubleshooting any issues. Another lesson I learned is that to get anywhere in this field you have to be prepared to give up all of your time and work somewhere with no windows. I realised that I did not actually want what I dreamt of. That is the way with most dreams unfortunately. You spend a lot of time and effort to get there and it might turn out that you do not actually like what you fought for. Nonetheless, I would still do it all over again, it was a brilliant course, I learned a vast amount, and met some amazing people, including my partner. Luckily the Tonmeister course does not only turn you into a great sound engineer, but also gives you an amazing all-round technical education. That is how I managed to get a job as Design technician at Environ Audio Ltd. These are the guys I resigned from today, about four years after I started. Environ are a custom AudioVisual company, working in the ultra-high end of the residential market, providing Home Technology solutions from Design through to installation and commissioning. Working for Environ has been great, both for what I learned, but also the relationship with the owners, who are great people. I have had the chance to grow so rapidly, from Design technician to Design Manager, via Lighting system programmer and in the last year managing projects, both in terms of Design but also on a site level. What I have not talked about so far, is how while everything above was happening, I discovered coding, and rapidly got hooked. At Uni, one of the courses included designing software to manipulate simple sound waves into complex synthesisers, using MaxMSP. I spent so much time working on this, thinking about better ways to do the same thing, and adding any (useful) new features I could think of. I found great pleasure in programming. Since then, I have been doing/studying programming in my spare time. A few months ago I started following this great course made available for free by Stanford University. I had no tangible goal in mind, other than learning for the sake of it and because I enjoy it. It is only after a long Christmas holiday that it struck me: the first day back at work it felt very strange and I realised I want to try make programming what I do. About a month and a lot of pondering later, I am looking ahead to start at MakersAcademy and I just cannot wait. I have decided to write about this for a number of reasons, the main one being that I think the very act of writing about what and how I am learning will help engrain it in my mind. Other reasons: a nice way document and look back at my experience at Makers; get better at talking about code outside my own head; reflect on what I am learning and set goals; take a shot at winning the Makers' blog competition prize! During the course, I will try to take a few minutes daily to write down what has been happening and then put it all together at the end of each week. Until then, I might be more sporadic! For now, here are a few thoughts about what I hope to improve throughout the course: - Talking about code. - Slowing down. I get very excited if I think I have found a solution to a problem and franctically type down code and run a test. Stop, consider all options, write elegant code and understand it. - Similar to the above. There is SO much to learn, and sometimes I jump between books/articles as I try to take in as much as I can. As I expect we will be taught at Makers, I should accept that I know very little and take one small problem at a time. Finally, I have another small dream, which coding might allow me to fulfill. Work from the beach! This is very close to where I am from originally in Italy. Thinking about it, I would probably get very little done and spend most time in the sea and sipping on Aperol Spritz, but I guess the idea is that the a remote job will allow me to spend some time working from home in Italy and going to the beach when I am not working! And eat some awesome fish, just like my dad in the picture below (I love fish!). I just cannot wait.

item.title: The leap of faith - aka metaclass confusion
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_189" align="alignnone" width="2087"] Petty Officer 1st Class Michelle Turner, U.s. Navy (www.defense.gov) [Public domain][/caption]
This week I have discovered that there is something I just have to take for granted, at least for now. I have a feeling it is not going to be the last time this happens...
Before I can talk about the issue, I need to explain what object-oriented programming is.
Certain programming languages (including Ruby, which I am learning at the moment) can be described as object-oriented. In an object-oriented environment, everything is an Object. I am going to use a real-world example to describe what an object is.
Let us take vehicle as an example. The main features of an object are its state(s) and behaviour(s). A vehicle's main behaviours are move, stop, load_item, unload_item. It can start moving if it was stationary or stop if it was moving; it can add an item to carry and drop it once it has reached destination. Its states are moving?, items_carried and colour, describing, respectively, whether the vehicle is moving or not, how many items it is carrying and its colour. Nice.
[caption id="attachment_193" align="aligncenter" width="3648"] "Sinclair C5 Driver" by Adam is licensed under CC BY-SA 2.0[/caption]
Now, for the concept of class. The vehicle's behaviours and states are described and encapsulated in the Vehicle class, which is the idea of a vehicle rather than one particular instance of it. You can have a number of vehicles moving items around, each with their own state, doing different things. All these vehicles are objects that belong to the Vehicle class.
I love how this concept is very similar to Plato's Theory of Forms. Even better, Plato's forms are to be Capitalised, just like classes -like Vehicle- in Ruby.
Next concept, class extension. A certain class can be extended to a new class. The new class inherits all the behaviours and states ª of its 'parent' class, which is called its superclass. The point in doing this is creating classes that are more specialised. For example, the Vehicle class could be extended into a new Car class, or Bus, or Wheel_barrow, you name it! 
All these new classes have more specific behaviours and states but they are all Vehicles, thus inherit the fundamental behaviours and states of a Vehicle: they can all carry items, move if static, stop if moving, have a colour, etc. Isn't this cool?
Ok, now onto the leap of faith.
In Ruby, every class you define belongs to the primordial class Object ª. In other words, for any given class, if you keep going up the inheritance tree, you will eventually get to the Object class. Ok, this is fine, for instance, from the example above,
SUV--is a-->Car--is a-->Vehicle--is a-->Object.
Here is the conundrum: Object is a class, in fact, you could say it is 'the' class, given that all other classes descend from it. However, there is a class named Class ! And guess what, this class is a descendant of the Object class, but the Object class is an instance of Class at the same time.
Class--is a-->Object--is a-->Class ª.
[caption id="attachment_208" align="aligncenter" width="1140"] By photo courtesy of National Security Administration / Nevada Site Office [Public domain][/caption]
What?!? This is like saying Class is both the child and parent of its parent, Object.
Well, there it is, my leap of faith. I just have to take this for granted now. See this article for more confusion.
ª (I am oversimplyfying here to keep this in layman/laywoman's terms)

item.title: Pizza, coding and GitHub
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: Today my flatmate and I made and sold pizze at the Farmer's Market in Oval. That's Ivan in the picture. It was pretty cold and we had freezing wind on our faces the whole time, but it was pretty fun to finally some sell pizza. We designed and built the trailer from scratch; the whole thing is self sufficient, is carried around by a bicycle and can make up to 70 pizze in one session. Cool no? Look at it go on the road! Ok, enough non-coding related talk. I have not been able to do that much coding in the last week, as I was away skying most of it. Got a few Codewars challenges done and read through The Well Grounded Rubyist a bit. Here's a cool pic I took on top of the mountain; you can see my girlfriend Liz and our friends Steph and Mich. Anyway, something I have been wanting to work on but have not got around to do yet is get some practice on GitHub. I think the best way would be to put together a simple project in Ruby and track it on GitHub. I got my inspiration for this on Holiday: lots of payments were made by one person for a group of friends, and I kept track of it all to then enter onto a spreadsheet and figure out who owes whom what. How much better would it be if there was an application where you could just enter name of the person, how much they paid and then the program can tell you who owes who and what?!? Well, I will only be able to make something that runs on IRB and I am not quite sure if I will be able to save the status to reopen and add new entries later, but I guess this is more than good enough for practising on GitHub. Ok, this is what I figured so far in terms of design. There will be two classes: Person and Receipt. Each instance of Person will store how much each person has spent and a hash containing how much they owe to the others. The Receipt class is going to have one instance per trip. Each trip has an array of hashes containing every single expense as follows: ski_trip_2016 = [{date => date of expense, total_paid => price on receipt, paid_by => person who paid, paid for => who the expense was for, description => quick description }, ...] Each receipt object will store the total expenditure, as well as update how much a certain person has spent and how much each person owes the others. Mm reading the above it is a bit confusing but this is the first time I ever think about program design..hopefully I will make more sense of it soon! In addition to writing the classes above I will also need to write the main program to run a session in IRB and then think about saving and loading existing trips. You can follow my progress on GitHub.

item.title: First encounter with Recursion
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_259" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Circles, 7 levels of recursion by fdecomite is licensed under CC-BY 2.0[/caption] It has finally happened. Out of nowhere, while working on the solution to a problem on codewars, I just did it, I used recursion! It was magic. Recursion is something I had known for a while but always figured I should leave it as something to learn later as it is a fairly advanced topic for someone who has just started. In computer science, recursion is a process whereby a function invokes itself. Here is a simple example: [f(x) = x + f(x + 1)] Well, although simple, the above is useless, as it creates an infinite loop and never yields a result. Try to substitute x with any number and work out the result to see how the function keeps calling on itself, forever! So what is the point with recursion? The trick is in defining a function the eventually reaches a stop. Building on the example above, we could arbitrarily impose that the function will return 0 if x is larger than say 3. Let us try and work out the result for x = 0 then. First the new definition: [f(x) = x + f(x + 1)], return 0 if x > 3 f(0) = 0 + f(1) f(1) = 1 + f(2) f(2) = 2 + f(3) f(3) = 3 + f(4) f(4) = 0, since (x > 3) Building backwards, f(3) is 3, so f(2) is 5 and f(1) is 6, giving us f(0) = 6. Recursion -when possible- offers a much more elegant solution to its non-recursive counterpart (at least I think, as I am not an expert!). Recursion is a little magic, as it allows an infinite process to be generated from a finite statement. For it to be useful in computing, the infinite process has to stop at some point, but still, pretty neat, no? Ok, in other news, I am quite excited about the MakersAcademy precourse for my cohort starting in 2 weeks! I have also met with one of the people in my cohort, which was nice and check out this cool project of hers: she made a smart mirror! Ciao

item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_333" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Slow Down, this is Moloka'i by 4nitsirk is licensed under CC-BY-SA-2.0[/caption] The precourse has finally started; I am still at work for another week but after than I will be fully dedicated to this. Last night was the launch event, where I got to meet the peeps on my cohort, although I feel like I only scraped the surface as there are 40 of us!! Anyway, I have just done a fresh reinstall of OSX and am ready to get my head stuck into all there is for us to learn (which is endless!). As I read through the 'table of contents' of what we are to get through I am  getting more and more excited, there is so much and I love this, and I am opening new windows, starting a youtube Video of a lecture here, reading a bit of a Wiki page there...I need to slow down. And this is what this post is about: I need to make a serious commitment towards focusing on learning one thing at a time, step by step, or else I will only be jumping between topics like a crazy frog (sorry about that). There is just so much for us to take in, yet the best way to go about it is to take it easy and let everything settle in, so here it goes: I promise I will do my best to focus on one thing at a time, favouring deeper and solid knowledge of fewer concepts over marginal, mnemonic  understanding of more. Should I be distracted by new topics whilst focusing on one, I shall keep a note of what that is and go back to it later. There it is, now I have written it down I will look like a fool if I do not go by it!

item.title: Command Line: friend or foe?
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_375" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Matrix-data-waterfall by Yoel Ben-Avraham is licensed under CC BY-ND 2.0[/caption] Pre-course week is coming to an end. I am still working at my soon-to-be previous job, so this week has been pretty intense, waking up early to study before work, and then rushing home (well, after one mandatory game of table tennis) to study into the night. It might be tiring, but I am loving it! Learning the Makers way is great: they tell you where you need to get to, give you tools to get there, but you are doing the walking and figuring out (slightly obscure methaphor, hopefully makes sense). This week I have also discovered the marvellous world of typing; yes, typing. It sounds silly, but I have never formally learnt to type on a keyboard, which means I am not a very fast typer. There is this little fun website where you can race, either solo or socially and my top speed is just over 50 words per minute, which is not at all impressive. I am re-learning to type using this website, which makes for a fun break! On the subject of typing, I am also learning vim, which is a terminal text editor worth having under your belt. In fact, I am typing the draft for this post using it! The focus of this week has been command line and Git. I am only going to talk about the former. In general, command line describes one way in which the user interacts with the machine. When using command line, there are no graphics, only lines of text, one after the other. Each line is either the computer 'talking' to the user, or vice-versa. For instance, the computer might say something like: "I am currently looking at the Downloads folder and am ready for commands." And the user might say: "Add a folder called Pictures and move all my pictures into it". Cool no? Another way the user can interact with the computer is using a graphical interface, which is the most common way (the one we all know), as it is easier to pick up and looks nicer (not as cool though!). Now for a bit more jargon. Both the command line and graphical interfaces can be referred to as "shell". The name is not accidental: the core level of computer operations is called "Kernel" and is very difficult for a human to 'talk' in Kernel language. So the shell is wrapped around the Kernel and allows us, the human, to talk to the Kernel and get it to do things for us. The shell is really just a translator. Staying on the methaphor, there are different languages we may speak (i.e. command-line or graphical user interface), and different translators to translate each language into Kernel language. The most used command-line dialect (sorry, I really like methaphors, and there is more than one command-line language!) is called Bash, which is what we have been learning this week. I made a little drawing to exemplify the human-shell-kernel concept. The command line used to be the only way we could interact with computers, however, fast forward a few decades and there are some pretty attractive alternatives, namely the various graphical user interfaces we are used to, be it the latest Window or OSX. The question is: why do we use command line? Is it better? Is it worse? I think the answer is - it depends. For the average user, the graphical interface is incredibly easy to pick up , intuitive and requires very little knowledge of its 'language': we know we can move the pointer to a file, double click on it to open it, or drag and drop it on a different folder, or right click for more options, etc. On the other side, we have the command line, which requires the user to learn the various arcane commands like 'cp' or 'rm' or 'cd' to achieve the same results. So far not so good for command-line. Why go through the pain of learning all the syntax? A world of programmer-perks awaits. Here are a few:
  • Faster processing speed. This might seem useless if you think about copy/pasting one file, but when dealing with vast amounts of files to process, a shell that has no graphics to worry about is a faster shell.
  • No mouse, faster human. Although it takes learning the syntax and being a quick typer, having hands stuck to the keyboard and not having to touch the mouse speeds thing up.
  • Fewer steps to achieve the same thing. This can be explained with an example: suppose we want to move a file "TEST.TXT" into its parent folder.Here are the steps required in command line: a) type mv TEST.TXT .. And these using a graphical user interface (one of the ways it could be done): a) right-click on the file, press 'cut' b) navigate to the parent folder c) right-click somewhere in the folder, find a bit of empty space, right-click and press 'paste'
  • A command-line environment like Bash also allows you to use scripts to automate processes.
I am sure there are numerous other advantages as well as disadvantages, but I am going to stop here. The main point is that all these advantages are good for programmers but useless for non-programmers (or at least the gains are not worth the effort), which is why programmers still use command-line and others do not! Ciao

item.title: Pre-course week 2: officially unemployed.
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
Thursday was my last day of work at Environ, which included a fantastic sendoff and even a few tears. Thank you Dan and Ben.

Week two of the pre-course is also coming to an end and I am loving it so much: I am excited with how much and what we are learning and how much more there is to learn (although it is important I learn one thing at a time, as I promised I would here!).

This week we have moved on to Ruby and have had a few challenges to solve simple problems in Ruby. We are also to amass as many points as we can on codewars, which is awesome! Even though I have spent most of my 2 months coming up to the course studying the language and playing on codewars, there is still so much for me to learn.

Some pair programming, both remote and in-person, happened. Pair programming is simply the process of tackling a problem as a pair: one person is 'driving' i.e. they hold the keyboard and actually do the typing, whereas the other person is 'navigating', discussing how the problem is being approached, checking for any mistakes and providing a different perspective; every so often (I think 25 minutes seems to be the norm) the roles are swapped. The amazing thing about this is the sharing of knowledge; both the people and the code benefit from this process. I am a big fan of the idea that we can all help each other by sharing knowledge and benefit from the process as a society rather than protecting what we know and our ideas from others. This is very similar to how open source works. Very nice no?

Ok, final thought: I really like pseudo-coding. It consists in taking my hands away from the laptop and thinking about a problem from a macroscopic point of view, without getting caught up in the small picture/s. As a novel programmer what often happens is that you are given a problem and start forcing the few things you know into a solution, without really knowing where your code is headed. With pseudocoding, you think about the bigger picture and sketch it on a piece of paper, without worrying about the details; this creates a framework for you to then start coding. I am trying to develop my own standard of symbols to pseudocode; for instance, the picture below shows a loop with some conditional logic in it. (Please ignore the actual content).

That's it, ciao.

item.title: The importance of carrying a compass (pre course wk 3)
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_433" align="aligncenter" width="3264"] The view from my parents' house[/caption] (Disclaimer: there are a few paragraphs that are not strictly about coding. If you want to cut to the chase, start from right after the picture with food on it!) It has now almost been 3 weeks since the precourse at Makers started and I am in bliss. It is a fantastic mixture of gorging on new information, self-improvement, moments of frustration followed by insta-satisfaction when solving a problem, and constant discovery...sounds good? It sure does to me. Time is flying and it seems there are not enough hours in a day to learn as much as we need to with the course. Anyway, brace yourself, my little brag moment is coming. I have spent this week back at my home town, Potenza Picena, in Italy. It is a tiny village at the top of a hill and very, very close to the Adriatic sea. See below a picture of my office this week ;) Isn't it awesome?? I have been going to the beach every morning and studied the day away with the sound of the sea splashing away in the background. One day I hope to spend some of my time working from here (or somewhere similar). I have also heavily indulged in the local cuisine; fish is my favourite thing. Below is a picture with a selection of the things I ate. Delicious. Ok, now onto serious business and, incidentally, the reason for this post's title; the importance of bringing a compass. The more I go on with the course and coding in general, the more I realise how important it is to have a compass for most, if not all, things. What I mean by compass is a tool (or tools) to keep track of where you are and where you are going, without deviations. Ooops, that is the definition of a compass, so let be more specific and tell you about my compass. In writing this post, I am using two tools: the pomodoro technique and a bunch of bullet points on what I want to write about and in which order. The pomodoro technique helps with focusing on one task at a time, with frequent short breaks to keep the mind sharp and one simple rule: if any distraction arises, write it down and deal with it later. This is even more important in programming, especially for a novice developer like me. It is tempting to jump onto the keyboard as soon as I am given a problem to solve, trying to make it work with a specific method I have in mind, but no clear picture of what I am really doing and where I am going! Twenty minutes later, either the code is messy, or I get frustrated and realise I should have stepped back, thought about the problem and made a plan. Doing this in the first place saves time and it is quite nice to have a plan. I talked about this in a previous post. In other news, this week I broke my laptop. I mysteriously find that cool and funny. What happened is I somehow created a shortcut to the root folder into one of my repositories and then wiped my laptop trying to get rid of it (idiot!). The reason why I am so relaxed about this is that all of my data is up in the cloud, so 4 hours later I had the Operating System reinstalled, along with all the tools I need and as if nothing had happened :) One major thing to learn here: do not try to delete all contents of the root folder and mindlessly answer 'yes' when the computer gives you a chance to redeem yourself! Finally, I am trying to become a Vim ninja. Vim is a text editor, like Word is, however there is no mouse nor pretty tabs and buttons in Vim: everything is done from the comfort of the keyboard and it is as dry as it gets. Sounds awful I hear you say? Well it is, at least to start with, but stick with it and you will move through a text file like wind and perform any sort of edits at the speed of light. It also means that no matter what machine you are using, there are strong chances that you will be able to use Vim. I am Vimming everything, even this post (see photographic proof below). So the course is starting on Monday, which is like WOoOoOoOoO, so exciting I wanna shout and just cannot wait! I changed the colour of my hair to celebrate this and I think it looks nice. Take a look! I am writing this from vim, which is the only text editor I am now using. I have printed out a few charts with commands and try to learn how to speed typing up whenever I suspect I could be doing something faster. I talked about vim briefly here. Hopefully one day I will be a mini vim-wizard and write a more in-depth post about it. This week I have paired with one of my lovely peers Van over the Fizzbuzz kata in Ruby. It was very nice. I love pair programming: it is so good for staying on track, learning and teaching (or rather sharing knowledge). It also makes it much harder to leave messy code behind you (not that I ever intend to do that!). Note for self is to always make sure I leave more than enough 'space' for the other person, as it is easy to just spurt out what I know, but it takes a slightly bigger effort to stop and listen. I do not think I am too bad at this but it is good to be aware of it. I also got to 400 points on codewars and solved a 3Kyu challenge! Finally, I started looking into TestDrivenDevelopment. In a nutshell, TDD is a (relatively) new way to approach writing code, which is part of Agile methodologies. Rather than writing a piece of code and then devising a test to check if it works, the opposite is done. That is, first a test is written, then the code to make it pass. The test defines an expectation on the code, for example one could say "the function shout is expected to return the string 'ARGH!' when called". The code is then written to satisfy the test. This has a number of advantages; using small and clear tests allows us to keep track of what is required from the program and avoid going off the rails with additional features that were not on the brief. It also helps dealing with few small problems at one time, as we work on one test at a time. A great side effect of this methodology is the fact that the suite of tests also double up as documentation on the code. I have not officially started adopting this yet, but I shall soon 'force' myself to only use TDD. It will feel backwards and slower at first, but I will stick with it and write some clean, well documented code. That's it, ciao!

item.title: This is incredible! (Makers week 1)
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
Here is a beautiful thing we were taught this week: in an Agile community, the only way someone can grow is by helping someone else grow. This is the foundation of mentorship. Isn't this great? We help each other grow and as a result we all improve as a community; beautiful. I might cry :)

Here is a quick example our (awesome) coach Sam gave us, using Bloom's model pictured above. We are all different, and if two individuals are at a different levels of learning, say apply and understand, if the one who is ahead helps the one behind apply the concepts they understand, that will have helped them move one move to the apply level, the other on the analyse level, as analysis is required in order to properly explain how to apply something to someone. Both parties are winners.

All this ties in with concepts of open source, whereby community collaboration is a very powerful tool.

OK, one week of Makers main course has gone and I am extremely happy about this. If you are reading this blog trying to make up your mind about makers, DO IT! It is awesome. It feels like time flew yet at the same time felt like a month rather than a week due to the huge amount of things we have learned.

Makers is serious business, yet everyone is relaxed, helpful and nice. It feels like home rather than work.

This is my daily routine: wake up (7am), go to Makers (8am) code, code, code, pingpong, code code, lunch, code code, code, pingpong, dinner, code code, sleep. It is now the weekend, and guess what I will be up to? I cannot get enough; there is always something else to learn and something that could be done better. It might sound daunting to some, but I love it: we are on a path of constant improvement for the rest of our lives.

Among the gazillion things we have learned this week, one that is almost completely new to me and I particularly liked is the BehaviourDrivenDevelopment (BDD) rationale. I will try to explain.

For any piece of software, we have a user, some sort of machine the user 'speaks' (interfaces) to, and a programmer who told the machine what to do. Simple. By the way, the machine could be a website, a mobile app, an ATM, a self-driving car, etc...The only point in the machine and the programmer existing is because the user needs the machine to do something useful, be that a game, payment, calculator, train information, you name it.

Now, when a user comes out with the requirement for a new piece of software, the most logical place to start is what the user wants from this new thing. Seems logical when put in perspective but it is easy for a software developer to loose sight of this and implement features for the sake of it, even if the user did not ask for them. This is not over delivering, this is complicating things, making the process slower and potentially annoying the user with a product they did not ask for.

Anyway, in BehaviourDrivenDevelopment (I hate acronims) the process of delivering a piece of software is driven by the user requirements. These are condensed into 'User stories', which read something like this:

  As an air traffic controller

  So I can get passengers to a destination

  I want to instruct a plane to land at an airport and confirm that it has landed

  ......

(this is from this weekend's challenge at Makers by the way) Succinct, nice and clear. Delivering the features described in a user story should remain the focus throughout the process. They might change as the Client develops their understanding of what they need or develop new requirements, but that is ok, we just need to update the user stories.

Now the user stories help the developers create 'feature tests'. These could be described as trying the software out before it even exists. This will generate errors as the machine does not know what to do. Solving those errors is how we write software.

For example, in the airport traffic control user story above, a feature test could be writing something like this: <Plane ID:333215152; land!>. Our expectation is for the machine to confirm that the plane has landed, something like <ID:333215152 status: landed>, however, the machine will complain that it does not know what a plane is, let alone IDs and landing!

The next step in BehaviourDrivenDevelopment is to move onto what is called Unit test, and the domain of TestDrivenDevelopment. This is very similar to BDD, but more 'zoomed in' on the individual components of a program. Much like we have done before, ahead of writing any working code, tests are written, clearly outlining our expectations on the code.

Going back to the example we might now write test to check that a plane and airport exist, and the plane knows what land means and how to do it. It is easy to see that there are several Unit tests for one feature test.

This process is cyclic, as we keep writing tests that fail, then make them work by writing code, something else fails, we make it work, and so on until we can go back to our initial feature test (in this example we wanted to land a specific plane) and it magically works.

Awesome, I like it and it makes a lot of sense. If this was not enough, there are (at least) two more intrinsic advantages: the code we write comes 'pre-tested', as opposed to writing something and then figuring out how to test it and the tests act as documentation on the code, as they outline all the requirements. Wow, I am impressed!!

That is it. As a side note I am fully converted to vim and have started picking up tmux, which is exciting!

Ciao

item.title: Good programming == good people
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_507" align="aligncenter" width="1599"] Rainbow flag breeze, by Benson Kua, is licensed under CCBY-SA-2.0[/caption] Another week at makers, this is still amazing, and if I look back at the first day, it feels like months ago, but it was actually less than two weeks ago. So much can be learned and done in a day, and there is even some time for table tennis! I also had the chance to know a lot of my peers better, as well as some people from the upper cohort /graduates. All of which are awesome and interesting people. One of the things I am very happy to have learned this week (or at least started to learn..) is that I need/want to make myself as humble as I can and listen to what other people have to say. Of course I still contribute with my own ideas, but listening and trying to understand what other people have to say is a goldmine of ideas and fresh approaches to any problem. This is what happened: in more than one occasion, I found myself discussing a certain topic with others and only being interested in letting them know my thoughts, which is very arrogant and assumes that I always know better. I would let them speak out of courtesy, but I was not really listening and just waiting for my turn to dish out the 'truth'. As soon as I noticed this behaviour, I told myself off, made myself humble again, and started to really listen to what they had to say, which means I am learning more and faster, and at the same time I am contributing to their learning. For instance, this week my pairing partner and I started sketching all the classes in a program on a whiteboard, and the more people gathered around us to contribute, the better the design got. The contributions would not come from one person only, but from different people, who each brought their own approach and knowledge to the problem. In short, a community of brains is a lot better than one brain. Wonderful thing is it not? I took a picture of the board at some point, here it is! Last week I wrote about Behaviour Driven Development, which is software development that focuses on the user interaction with the product first before worrying about the underlying software architecture. As I am reading about the subject, there is a really interesting point made in 'The RSpec Book' written by David Chelimsky that I would like to share. The book talks about how traditional software can fail due to excessive design from the beginning of the project. It explains: the main problem is that software is being designed like buildings, where it gets expensive to get anything wrong (think about having to take down and rebuild a wall). Because of this, the specification of the final product has to be very accurate and detailed from the outset, so that no mistakes are made; the main problem is that the end user -the client- does not fully know what they want until the building starts taking shape and then they change their minds about what it is that they really wanted. This is natural but can be costly, which is why a buildings' design has to be very strict and detailed. However, the only cost in software is people's time. Spending too much time upfront trying to pin down something that not even the end-user knows can be wasteful. Instead, a Behaviour Driven Development approach recommends starting from a small client requirement and grow the project organically by releasing a finished product very early so the client can figure out what it is they really wanted and let the production team know. This might happen a few times, with each iteration helping the client and team shape the final product. In other words, the design is allowed to evolve rather than be written in stone at the beginning. A benefit of this is that new features and changes to existing ones are much easier to implement. Pretty cool idea I say! Ok, that is it, now onto writing a take-away system for the weekend challenge! Ciao

item.title: I smashed my headphones and now I am a better programmer!
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
>--- copy/paste the usual excited comments about how great the course is here ---< Looking back at my posts about the course, I have realised I always start with how exciting and awesome this all is. I am sorry for anyone following (give us a shout if you are there!) if I sound like a broken record, but this is genuinely amazing: the community, the learning, the principles! Plus you can just skip the first paragraph and move on to the *very* interesting material below :)

Something fun happened this week: I accidentally broke my headphones while playing table tennis. I left them on the floor and literally jumped on them while playing. You can find photographic evidence at the top of the page.

Ok, breaking headphones is not that fun, I will admit, especially if you paid for them, however what was fun is that breaking them made me realise how well designed they are (they also sound pretty good and are extremely comfortable, but that's irrelevant here). If you are thinking 'how is this at all related with programming??', I will explain soon enough. What makes these headphones great (Sennheiser HD 25-1 II by the way) is their modular design, where each element is responsible for one thing only: there is a plastic headband that is responsible for holding the assembly onto one's head, the cable that connects the headphones to the source (I know, all headphones have a cable, but can you unplug it and replace with a new one?), the speaker elements in a plastic cup, and the foam pads, responsible for making the headphone comfortable (these are modular too and can be replaced). Do not take my word for it: take a look at the picture below of all the components.

Now, I would like to compare the design of these headphones, which is modular, with ones that are not modular, meaning that you could not take them apart without breaking them.

In my case, because my headphones are modular, I can simply throw away the head band, buy a new one and save myself a lot of money. I would have had to buy a new pair of headphones with a non-modular pair. Also, if Sennheiser come out with some fancy coloured foam pads and I want to have a different style every day, I am simply buying 7 inexpensive pads instead of a lot of non-modular headphones! Enough? How about Sennheiser themselves? They can easily reuse any of the components in any other product. For example, if they wanted to have a cheaper version of the unit with lower quality speakers, all they need is new cups as they already have the head band and cable. Awesome. Last one, I promise: how about a new manufacturer comes out and they are very good at making the speaker cup but do not have the capacity to make cables, foam pads and head bands? They can just reuse Sennheiser's parts.

Hopefully I have convinced you that modular design is generally better than monolithic one.

Now on to programming. One of the principles of good object oriented design is single responsibility. Just like my headphones, classes -the building blocks of a program in object-oriented languages- ought to be responsible for one thing only. When designing a class I try to bear in mind what each class' responsibility is. In fact, I make a little diagram with all my current classes and write down their responsibility amongst other things. When I add any new features to the program, knowing what each class is responsible for helps me decide whether the new feature can be implemented extending the existing classes or if I need new ones. The reasons and advantages of classes with single responsibility in programming are very similar to the headphones example: any class can be reused in any other program if well isolated and only responsible for one thing; also, a clear division of responsibilities normally allows a simple and easy to follow (for a human) flow of messages between instances of the classes.

So this is why I was happy to have broken my headphones.

One final thought from this week: diversity is great. Diversity means different approaches to the same problem, and different ideas to contribute to an overall stronger community. As I am pair programming with a different person every day, I have to come to really appreciate how much there is to learn from everyone around me. Seeing how different people approach the same problem is a fantastic learning tool. I really like how a program either works or not, but there are many ways to make it work, some better than others.

Now onto weekend solo-programming :) Ciao

item.title: Database, filesystem, warehouses..say what?!
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: EDIT (please notice that having only just heard about databases, the information below is partially incorrect) I normally only write posts at the end of the week whilst here at MakersMakers but this one is part of a task I am currently working on, which includes writing a blog post on databases :) Let's try to make it simple, by stating the obvious. Data is not very useful unless it can be stored and retrieved later on. When I say data, this could be anything from a movie, a number, a picture, some text..It does not matter, as at the end of the day, it will be stored as ones and zeroes. Ok, so there is a concept called 'persistence' of certain data. Data that persists outlives the functioning of the device it is stored in. In other words, a persistent way of storing a picture is by writing it onto a USB stick; once written, even if the USB stick turns off, we will still be able to retrieve the file in the future. It is harder to give an example of  non-persistent storage systems (cache would be an example), but please just trust that there are systems that only store data temporarily and will lose it if turned off. Nice, so now we have the obvious and the definition of persistence out of the way, let us talk about how computers store any data. One way is to use a FileSystem. This is what we are used to. Without going into too much detail (mainly because I would not be able to :D ), FileSystems allocate memory for data and know where they are located. In order to retrieve data within a filesystem, the user has to know the 'path' to the data. Even if you use Finder (in OSX) or Explorer (in Windows) and do a search, you are looking for the path to the data, which you have to know in order to retrieve the data. A database is just another way to store data; I am going to describe a relational database, again, mainly because this is the only one type of database I know at this time. I will use an analogy, as this helped me understand it better. The FileSystem described above could be thought of as a warehouse, with a rigid internal structure: you store data in a certain room and you need to be able to 'navigate' back to that room if you want to retrieve a specific piece of data. If you know what you want, you can search for it, 'navigate' there and retrieve it. But what if you are not sure about what you want, or you want all data that shares a certain attribute? Well, enter relational databases: these can be compared to a 'magical' warehouse, where rooms can reshuffle and move around to present you with the relevant data, without the need for you to 'navigate' around the warehouse. How is this possible, I hear you say? In a relational database, data is stored in tables. Each table is called 'relation', students could be the relation in our example. Any data we will store in our students table will be data about students. Simple no? Ok, refer to my beautiful sketch below; each row (also called tuple - don't ask me why!) is an entry in the table, so it corresponds to a student. Each column is an attribute. Attributes give additional on the data; in fact, attributes are data themselves, and could be of a number of types, like text, numbers, true/false, etc.   The powerful thing about databases is that we can retrieve data from them without knowing where it is, plus we can query specific subsets of data. For instance, we might want to retrieve all students who are over the age of 15, or any who are under 30 and from Italy. Ok, one final thing; as we need a way to write, read, update or delete from and to a database, we need a language to communicate to it. The most popular one today is SQL. Ciao

item.title: Meetups are the bomb!
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_623" align="aligncenter" width="442"] Meetup Logo 2015 is under CC-BY-SA-4.0[/caption] Another week has gone and Makers does not stop being an awesome ride. We are now a third of the way through, looking forward to the rest of it and learning Javascript next week. As of last week I have started going to quite a few tech meetups. Meetups are free events that feature a talk, workshop, hands-on session, or a mixture of the three. They are normally packed with very interesting people and most of them provide free pizza and beers (say what?!). I think it is virtually impossible to go to any meetup and it be a waste of your time: if all else fails, you get free dinner. One step up, you get free dinner and meet interesting people. Two steps up, you learn something, meet people and have free dinner! This is unreal!! What I love about meetups is that whoever organises them has no hidden agenda, they are not trying to sell you anything (at least not so far); their only interest is to contribute to the community by sharing knowledge gratuitously. The meetup I enjoyed most this week was a hands-on one, organised by the London Software Craftmanship Community. The event (a regular one, on Wednesdays) consists in a few people meeting up and coding together in pairs. I knew I was going to be the n00b in the room, but I am ok with that. The person I paired with was great and extremely kind and patient to teach me about functional programming. We paired over a kata (a short programming exercise) in Erlang and I was really excited to learn a bit about a new language and a bit about a fairly different programming paradigm from the one I am used to (Object-oriented). Also, I am extremely grateful to the person I paired with, as he took the time to explain concepts that are extremely basic for him. Again, lovely people in this community, who are happy to give up some of their time to help others out. Back to Makers, this week we have completed the web-architecture circle, with databases. These might seem trivial from the surface, but it turns out there is so much to take in, especially when put in context within the full stack. At some points this week I felt overwhelmed by how much there is to learn and worried about how fast I am learning and how many things I am learning about...Well it is time to remind myself about relaxing and learning one thing at a time, like I promised here. It is ok to feel like there is so much I do not know; in fact, I do not think I will ever feel like I know enough (hello Socrates!), which is one of my drives for continual learning. It is also a good idea to look back and marvel at how much I have learned since joining Makers. With so much to learn ahead of me, what if I could take in more information in a given period? I have recently heard about speed reading and am going to try learn to speed read. The idea is that instead of vocalising each word in our mind as we do with our voice, we take in a lot more information and increase reading time, whilst -allegedly- retaining the same level of comprehension. Sounds brilliant, but I remain skeptic until I see it work. Ciao

item.title: Frustration :)
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
Another weekday post; I did not write anything over the weekend and it turns out I miss writing a post plus it is quite nice to sit down and reflect on how this (the course) is all going. This is a first: I am frustrated and worried. It is not Makers' fault, it is probably mine, or maybe nobody's.
The problem is, we have dived into new technologies and are trying to learn them very fast. Too fast I feel. I like a deep understanding of my tools rather than making something work and not understand why. However time constraints sometimes mean we cannot have a full understanding of everything.
This week we have been divided into small groups of four to write a simple app that mimics the airBnB service. We were told we could do that with the language/frameworks we have just learned, or use different ones. With my group, we chose to opt for the latter, and boy is it a struggle. Having not much experience building full-stack apps, we are trying to make another one with an unfamiliar language, framework, database, testing framework....
The main reason for frustration is that I find myself often running in circles, starting something -be that an article, exercise, tutorial- and then interrupt and switch to something new as there is so much too learn and I do not want to take too long on any single thing. But at the same time I do want to take too long on everything, so I can be confident with my understanding of it; but there just is not enough time!
On top of that, it really does not feel like we are making any progress with our project, as the setup phase seems to have no end, and we are yet to write one line of code 1.5 days in...

Finally one thought: being in this with others that are having the same or similar problems does help and makes everything better.

item.title: Headless Zombies are coming!!
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_631" align="aligncenter" width="2048"] Zombie Beard, by Scott O'Donnel, is licensed under CC BY-2.0[/caption] Here we are, week 6 has just finised, which marks the halfway point through the course; I knew it was going too fast! As you might have read, this week I have been frustrated; there was just about too much we were struggling with within my team and at one point had spent a whole day getting nowhere. What happened is we decided to tackle this week's project using a set of technologies that was completely new to us. However things started moving from Wednesday and we have learned quite a bit since then. Granted, we are just scraping the surface and are by no means experts in what we learned, but you have to start somewhere, and I am sure learning something this way is much more persistent in the long term than canonical learning, being spoon-fed information. Anyway, what we spent most time researching before we could start writing the application was a framework to test the whole thing. And yes, before we write any code, we want to have a test for it that tells us what we expect from that code. We tried so many differenent options, and were not even completely sure what we really needed initially. Zombie was our saviour. Zombie is a NodeJS framework (Node is the main technology we were using) that allows you to have automated tests that do things like:
-> connect to the signup page -> fill in user information -> click 'submit' -> the page you land on should be hostaddress/specific_page_you_should_land_on -> the page should display the new username in the top section
So instead of running the server, connecting to it and checking features manually we had our friend the Zombie doing these things for us automatically. Thanks Zombie. The first time you send the Zombie, say with the instructions above, it will complain that the signup page does not exist, which makes you create one. Then it will complain there needs to be a signup form on the page, which makes you add one, and so on, driving both page content, navigation and, most importantly, logic. A funny thing is that Zombie is headless. OK, maybe not that funny; it has been a long week... Headless means it does not need a specific browser to connect to a server, it follows instructions as above and then checks the results. Let me explain further. There are three main ways to test a web application from the point of view of the end user. The obvious one is doing it yourself by manually connecting to the server with a browser and checking it is behaving as expected. This is not very reliable and can become painfully time consuming if we are trying to test several features. So one way to automate is having a webdriver that starts one of your browsers and runs the tests for you (this is oversimplified). This method also allows to check compatibility across multiple browsers/versions of the same browser, however that makes for a much longer setup and overkill for what we were doing. It is pretty cool to see your browser by a third party though, much like Neo being hacked in The Matrix (not really, but sure Andrea..). Finally we have the headless method described above, which is much faster and does not require an actual browser, instead it connects to a server directly and analyses its responses. Cool no? Final point on Zombies: there is a great song by Fela Kuti called Zombie, check it out. I am happy to say I have learned plenty this week, despite the initial hiccup. In fact, one of the biggest takeaways is how I should deal with failure and learning completely new things in a short span of time. The former is easier than it sounds: sucking at something is good :) It means that there is room to get better and getting better at anything is a lot of fun! It was much more difficult for me to learn new things quickly; my main problem with it is not being able to formulate a somewhat thorough understanding of the concept before being able to put it into practice. This slows me down. I am not saying having a shallow understanding of concepts is good, but, especially in programming, when learning completely new concepts, getting your hands dirty soon helps figuring things out and allows you to move on faster. This is related to a concept I am very fond of, information hiding, which I will talk about in the future. Today I am going to an event where everyone picks a new programming language; I plan to go for a functional one (a programming paradigm that is fairly different from the one we have been learning at Makers - object oriented). Quite excited to get started! That's it, Ciao.

item.title: Unicorns are running wild
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_668" align="aligncenter" width="2372"] Toy Unicorn Vector art by spacefem is under CC0/Public Domain licence[/caption] This week at makers was great. We were divided into teams of four people and asked to work on a project with minimal guidance. I am super happy about the team (ours was team unicorns) dynamics and proud of what we built, which can be found here and is available as a Node package, just install Node and type npm install unicorn-list in the root of your project directory. As I write this post, one day ahead of publishing the framework it has been downloaded 120 times, whaat??! The brief was to make a simple front-end app, which displays lists dynamically, based on a to-do list model. You can add items to the to-do list and then check a box next to the task to move them to the 'completed' pile. The really cool thing is that after doing this simple app, we were supposed to create a framework out of it, to make building a simple web app with dynamic lists uber-simple. What was awesome about our team is that we built everything from scratch, without using any other frameworks/libraries, starting from a static server in Node, whose only task is to read files from memory and send a copy to the client upon request. The server looks at the request url and determines which file should be read into a variable then sent as a response. We then went on to design and write a (very basic but awesome) templating engine. The engine takes a .cats file and renders any dynamic content based on conventions we established. See below an example .cats file, which is effectively the html template of your one-page app and contains some special syntax that the templating engine picks up and renders based on a javascript object that contains arrays of strings. Finally, we put together the whole thing as a Node package, which allows anyone to download the framework and get started in a few seconds. item.title: The importance of not understanding
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: Oh my, week 8 of Makers has already finished and the end of the course is approaching fast! It is still great fun and we are absorbing knowledge like big sponges in a big puddle (I know, awesome analogy right?). This week I ran another workshop for our 'juniors', which was a lot of fun; I really liked how some of them carried on working on the exercise I gave them and then sent me a solution later on during the day. I love people who care. I am trying to link these presentation I prepare with a common theme: simplicity. Simplicity is -I find- most important when approaching something as vast and complicated as programming (sorry for being a bit vague). Our heads (well, mine for sure) struggle to hold intricate designs and concepts at once and if there is anything we can do to make any task or any reasoning simpler and more pragmatic, then we should. In his great book 'The Software Craftsman', Sandro Mancuso describes how in one of his first jobs he was told off for writing some code that was too complex and hard to understand: everyone should strive for the simplest and most readable code they can, so that others will not struggle understanding it. Writing simple code might not be simple, but is fundamental. Last week's presentation was on using diagrams as a tool to help understand system design and interaction between classes in object oriented programming. Diagramming in general is a fantastic tool to help simplify our thoughts and solidify our understading of a system or process. This week I talked about the four-phase-test pattern, which helps break down our reasoning when writing a test for a certain behaviour in the application under the lens. All the presentations I made are available here and I would be more than happy to discuss or give them again, just reach out to me :) Ok, now onto what I learned this week and the reason for the title. In computer science (am I allowed to say that or am I just a programmer??) there is a fantastic concept called 'information hiding'. Due to the amount of complexity behind 'computer' systems, it is fundamental to hide certain aspects away in order to focus on a specific element. In other words, there is no need to understand the full extent of a system in order to operate on one part of it, as long as the system is nicely modular. Here is an example: the driver of a car does not necessarily need to understand how the engine and transmission systems work, they can just accept that engine/transmission somehow respond to our actions and move the car, based on a set of conventions, being the pedals, steering wheel, etc. So, moving back to computers and anything that can be programmed, as a programmer I do not have to deeply understand the inner workings of the processor and logic units in order to write useful programs; I can just see these as 'black boxes' and trust them to do what I expect them to. This concept also works within a program: I or someone else might work on a specific module for a long time to make it do something useful, but once we are done building it, the users of that module do not need to know about hot that module works, they just understand what it does and how to make it do the things it does. MAGIC. This week we have started learning Ruby on Rails, which is a web framework that allows you to build a web application super-fast. Learning Ruby on Rails heavily requires trusting the 'black box' I refer to above: the high complexity of what the framework does is hidden behind the simple and familiar-sounding keywords that Rails gives us to build the system. This week I have more than once had to stop myself from trying to understand how Rails does something and just trust the magic; this is information hiding at its best! So again, simplicity is paramount. Turns out simplicity is one of the extreme programming values...What a coincidence! Right I am going back to work now; this weekend I am building an Instagram clone using Rails. Ciao

item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_media-2" align="aligncenter" width="1050"] Raticate by Captain Shortstack is licensed under CC-BY-NC-ND 3.0[/caption] This week at makers was pretty ace! In anticipation of final project (next week and the one after), this week we did a mini-project, or as they call, it a Makerthon. On Monday, people pitched their ideas, which were then voted and a shortlist was made. We then assembled into teams of 4-6, more or less based on our first choice of project. I was in awesome BattleCodes team, and this is what we made (please let me know if you find any bugs). Battlecodes allows two programmers to race each other in solving a coding challenge. You connect, pick a challenge (which creates a room), share your room code with your friend and start racing. The game ends when one of the two players submits code that passes all tests. Cool right? It was amazing for me as I learnt about a new technology, websockets, which enables real-time web applications. We also designed and built our own mini-micro-tiny frontend testing framework, which we are pretty proud of. This is the 'engine' that evaluates the user's submitted solution against a set of expectations and publishes test results to both the user (in visual form) and the server (as raw data). If the test results are positive, the server knows to end the game and announce the winner. Coooool! It is marvellous to see how much can be achieved in a few days; it is also amazing to see how well a team self-organises if all the members are motivated. We had zero input from Makers and did produce our own schedule, task assignments, pair rotations, product specification, etc. In other words, self management is a powerful thing, especially as this enables everyone in the team to feel a sense of ownership over the project. When you want to work instead of having to work, you are happy :) We enjoyed doing this so much that there have been talks of expanding and improving the product for fun after Makers! So, as mentioned, next week the two-weeks final project begins. Exciting! Yesterday we had another round of pitching for projects; the shortlist was then announced and we each expressed our top-three preferences. I really hope I get to work in my top-choice, which is a 'smart mirror'. In short, this is a mirror with a screen behind it that is only visible when on. It can be (once we build it) customised to show many different widgets, such as custom weather, local traffic info, latest news, go wild! We might also add speakers to it, so that it can be programmed to, say, wake you up with your favourite song or radio station. Mood lighting do I hear you say? Sure, we can add an arduino to it, maybe it lights up and changes colours with music, or perhaps it gradually turns on and moves to full brightness to help you wake up. And calendar? Of course, sync up your calendar and today's schedule will be shown. Picture frame? why not, maybe as a screen-saver kind of thing. I could go on for a while, so I will stop now. My fingers are crossed and hopefully I will be working on this project as of Monday. Now back to do some coding! No weekend assignment this week as they told us to take a break but taking a break from coding sounds more like a punishment than anything else to me right now ;) Ciao

item.title: What is good quality code?
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
Hi :) As part of  applying for a position at a software consultancy, I have been asked to answer a few questions, including what I think 'good quality' is in code. How nice of them to ask! Seriously, this makes me want to work for them even more, but also it is a super interesting topic, as there is no simple and indisputable answer. Much like I love the fact that you can write software that does the 'thing' it is expected to do (this is binary: it either works or it does not) and then you can write software that does that same thing but is well written (and what well means here is far from binary). Anyway, enough with the introductions; here is my answer to the question. I would love to hear everyone's thoughts and imagine my position might evolve as I grow in my career.

How do you determine if software is "high quality”?

Please notice that the values below are general indicators of ‘high quality’ in software rather than axioms. Quality in software is not a binary attribute and is a debatable subject, which makes it even more fun.

Interestingly, some of the values below apply to good design in general, not just coding.

Simplicity_A simple solution to a problem might not be easy to find, but tends to be the best. Simple solutions are easy to reason about and modify/extend if necessary. Spending extra time upfront finding the most simple solution saves significant time down the line when a new feature can be easily implemented thanks to a simple design.   

Human-readability_The only reason software exists is because someone needs it to perform a certain function, be that for business, entertainment, health, etc. As people’s needs are always changing, software also needs to change and adapt. The most easy the code is to read, the easier it will be for the future programmers to implement new features. Simple code is key to human-readability; good naming of variables, classes, methods, etc. also has a significant impact on this.

Modularity_This is equivalent to the principle of single responsibility in object-oriented design; good software tends to be modular, whereby each part has a well-defined function that allows easy reuse, replacement and/or extensibility. I recently wrote a blog post about this (http://bit.ly/1tvyBZJ).

Ease of change_This goes in hand with modularity and readability: high quality software tends to require the least changes to implement a new feature.

Squint-test_This is more of a positive side-effect from the above than anything else. Credits to Sandi Metz for this idea. ‘High quality’ software looks good and neat, even without reading the contents. A page full of good code will look nice and regular when squinting at it.

Having written this a couple of weeks ago, I would like to add the following point: Principle of least surprise_Code should be very unsurprising, which ties in with all the values above. If the code is of good quality, any developer (of the appropriate skill level) should be able to approach a code base without being surprised and simply read through the application without scratching their head. I appreciate this point is very similar to the first one, but is worth stressing again. There is an interesting description of this in Sandro  Mancuso's book 'The Software Craftsman' where he tells about one of his first experiences in a large software company and his lead developer being annoyed at him for having used an arcane solution to a problem that most developers would find difficult to understand. Ciao

item.title: Hello Functional Programming
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: Hi. This week was the first week post Makers and I am really enjoying it, with a good mixture of job hunting, studying, working on tech tests and attending meetups. Went to Edinburgh for the Fringe over the weekend with Liz and our flatmates. Highlights: lots of laughs, fried haggis and a lovely walk on top of a hill, check out a picture of the view!     OK so I am starting to look into functional programming and I would like to talk about it. I do not know much about it so please do not use this as a reference and do not hate me if I say any travesties. In fact, please do let me know in the comments if there is anything I should rectify, or do get in touch to discuss :) Functional programming is a programming paradigm. The expression 'programming paradigm' describes the 'style' of programming. This is a bit vague (sorry), but effectively depicts the main features of a programming style, which can span over a number of concerns. Here is a -hopefully- good analogy: think of programming paradigms as music genres. A music genre summarises transversal features that songs of the same genre share; for example, dance music is often fast and makes heavy use of digital instruments. Much like music genres, the features described in programming paradigms are not always concerned with the same areas of concern; in the analogy, some genres describe a particular rhythm, others the way a singer sings, others the instruments used, etc. One of the -currently- most popular paradigms is Object Oriented, and is the one we were taught at Makers. In Object Oriented programming all (or most, depending on the language) data is described as an Object. An Object groups together (encapsulates) behaviour and state that belongs to a certain abstraction. Here is an example: let's invent an Object, Person. Now give this Object some behaviour; let's say a person can #grow, #eat, #sleep, #greet, #fight and #die. Do not forget to give this Object some state too; something like @age, @hunger, @tiredness and @health. Now we can generate a number of Person objects, and they will each have their own state (how old they are, how hungry they are..) and be able to interact with each other and the world around them. This is pretty cool. However there is something in this story that could cause a lot of pain. That is state. The problem with state is that it can get very complex very soon and generate unexpected results, also called side effects. Here is an example: if we use the #grow behaviour on a person, this will increase the @age state, which is what we expected, however after a certain age growing older might also decrease your health, which is a side effect. Side effects make our programs harder to test and unpredictable. What if we could do away with state? Enter Functional Programming. It is not that state does not exist; it does exist, but is immutable (cannot be altered). Functional Programming is all about functions as opposed to objects (as it says on the tin). Functions are used to transform data to into the desired result. A very important concept in functional programming is that of pure functions. The output of a pure function is always the same for a given input. A pure function has no side effects. Awesome, so we can trust a certain pure function to always behave in the same way (no mutable state exists to alter the result) and only do the one thing it promises to do. This keeps Uncle Bob very happy. Cool stuff right? I will be posting more on this as I find out more and reflect on it. Next time I should include some code examples too! Ciao

Hi, a tutorial you say? Indeed. This is my first one, so please bear with me. It is about a tiny thing in Rails called unobtrusive javascript, which I found very sleek, so a quick example follows. Uh, just before that, how could I not mention what is going on in my life..I am halfway through week 4 post Makers, having a great time learning more and speaking to potential employers. This week I am away in Italy with Liz :) here is a picture of the sea (it was rowdy today). So, unobtrusive javascript. Let's say your frontend needs to interact with the server, say to create a new entry in a database, or update an existing one. If you also want the page to somehow update dynamically using javascript, you would have to write some code that is loaded with the page, which prevents the default behaviour when the action is triggered, interacts with the server and updates the page with the JSON returned by the server. Fine. However, Rails has very nice feature whereby you can 'tell' the form that you are going to use javascript. This will automatically prevent the default behaviour plus allow you to forward a snippet of javascript back from the server to dynamically update the page. You can find out more on this guide. Anyway, to show how it works, I made a little repo, you can clone it here. Also feel free to fork it and open pull requests, however I am going to start from scratch in the tutorial. In this project, we create a page that shows movies. Nice. First of all, install rails: follow step 3.1 in this tutorial. Then initialise the Rails project and move into it:

rails new rails_unobtrusive_js && cd rails_unobtrusive_js

Create the movie model, which will store a title and description:

And a controller for it

Then, in the routes config file (./config/routes.rb) set up the movies' routes; for this tutorial we just want to be able to show all movies in the database as well as add new ones, so the file should look like this:

Ok, now let's create the :index action as well as the associated HTML view. In the movies controller (./app/controllers/movies_controller.rb), simply assign all existing movies to a variable; this will be used in the view.

Now create a view file for this (./app/views/movies/index.html.erb), where we simply iterate over the list of movies and display the title. We do so using Rails' view  helper render, which looks for the partial file and passes each movie to it. So here is the view, nice and simple:

And the :create action to the controller (./app/controllers/movies_controller.rb) to add a new movie to the database.

The action also knows to respond with some javascript to tell the browser what to do (see line 9 above). This is defined in a .js.erb file (./app/views/movies/create.js.erb); we can have it dynamically add the movie to the list of existing ones:

If however someone's eyes are opened as a result of reading this, then I would be very happy with the outcome. Hopefully you agree that in an ideal world every human being should be treated equally and have access to similar opportunities in life, regardless of where they are from, which family (or non-family) they were born in, what they believe in, the colour of their skin, physical or mental disabilities, their gender and sex. If you disagree, then please let me know why. I like to keep an open mind on anything, however I feel it is going to be hard to move my position on this one. If you are a white heterosexual, middle class male, then you are seriously at risk of not realising how unfair the job market is against anyone but your specific category. I certainly was oblivious until a few years ago. In a way, it is 'normal': when everything goes well, it is hard to realise we are privileged and society is geared towards favouring us. I am extremely thankful to have met my partner, Liz, who not only is an amazing individual, but also opened my eyes towards equality at work, and keeps doing so. Ok, now go take a look at this list of male privileges in the workplace. Please take some time to go through all of them. If you only remember one of the points, I would make it number 46:
46. I have the privilege of being unaware of my male privilege
In fact, being aware of the issue is a good start, but should not be the end of it. I think we should make it our duty to try and close the gap. If you do not know where to start, have a look at this list of things men can do to support feminism. I often volunteer as a coach at codebar, where underrepresented groups are given free coaching and support to learn programming. Hopefully this post managed to raise some awareness on the topic.
