item.title: Human beings are plastic
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1052" align="aligncenter" width="1648"] Ollie skateboard by RyanDavis199 is under CC BY-SA 3.0[/caption] I love how humans can -through sheer practice and perseverance- become experts at anything. This is perhaps not universally true, but has a number of applications. I especially like it when progress can easily be demonstrated. For instance, a few years ago, my friend and I decided to pick up skateboarding. Initially we could not even stand on the damn thing, but after a few days we could balance ourselves, and started learning to steer. We were practicing almost everyday and could clearly see improvement, until we hit the first big hurdle: the ollie. An ollie is the most basic trick there is. In short, it is jumping an obstacle. Now, jumping while you are on the board is one thing, but how do you lift the bloody thing up with your feet!?!? It seems to defy all laws of physics, but it is possible, and there there are many videos online that explain how to do it. And guess what, after a few weeks of deliberate practice and perseverance, we both managed to ollie! How rewarding!! Notice how another amazing thing is that the Internet empowers us to share or find resources on how to learn something (sorry for the boring obvious statements). Now the above might not apply to all of the things we want to learn, as some are much more complex and involve more than just muscle memory, but there are so many that do fit and we could easily learn/improve if we had clear goals and were consistent. For example, before I started coding, I could not touch-type. I realised if I was going to spend the rest of my life typing code, I should probably get better at typing. Since then, I have spent about 15 minutes a day practicing touch-typing on this site and can now see huge improvement, which is very useful and satisfying. And it 'only' takes 15 minutes a day. How easy is that?? The key is consistency; a few minutes a day for a couple of months make a serious difference. So think about your daily schedule, how easy would it be to set aside an hour to practice a few things that you want to get better at? If you make it a habit, you will be getting better and better at whatever you pick and once you are pro at it, pick a new thing. Dedication and will power are key:  I am sure we all can squeeze an hour somewhere every day, but it is much easier to be lazy and not do it. So what are you going to master in your practice hour? Make it public and track your progress, you will be amazed. PS: it works better if you do it at the same time every day.   Here is my plan:
  • Improve reading speed (currently roughly 180 words per minute), maintaining or improving comprehension. 20 min
  • Keep improving fast typing. 10 min
  • Exercise. Go for a run or a swim or anything that keeps me fit. 30 min
  • (maybe alternate playing the keyboard with exercise?)

item.title: Decomposing my personal development
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded: Ready for some cool news? I have a job!! Yes, I will be writing code in exchange of money. Awesome. I will be joining Deloitte Digital as a junior developer, although I will not be starting for a couple of months. In this time, I want to to keep growing as a developer everyday, but the prospect of doing this on my own is a bit overwhelming: how do I know what things I should be doing, what books to read; who is going to give me feedback on what I am doing? There is a concept in software engineering that I am very fond of, that of decomposition. In short, decomposition means taking a large problem and breaking it down into smaller sub-problems, to replace a one big problem with a few small (and easy to solve) problems. I used to do this at University, when I had to write essays. I really disliked writing essays, so to help me in the process, I would first break down the essay into big sections, then subsections of those, and further subsections and so on, until I was left with tiny bits of essay to write. I traded the scary empty page and blinking cursor with a few short 'forms' to fill. A nice side-effect of decomposing a problem into smaller components is that you can track your progress and clearly see how much you have done so far. So, in order not to feel too overwhelmed and to be more effective/accountable in this period, I have decided to make a plan for my personal development. I have made it public, so anyone can take a look and comment; here it is: http://bit.ly/2evxtlM. I will be using the pomodoro technique, deciding roughly how long I will be working each day and on what. As there is SO much I could learn, I need to make sure I stay effective and focused on a few things. That's it, please hit me with comments/feedback if you have any :) Ciao

item.title: Four things I like in tests
item.dc:creator: andreamazza89
item.content:encoded:
I really like test-driven-development (TDD). It helps me focus on what I am trying to achieve and keeps me on track. By testing first and writing code to make the test pass, we flesh out the problem we want to solve, and then find a way to solve it; thanks to the test we have, we immediately know once the problem is solved (tests go green). This is as opposed to vaguely knowing what we are trying to achieve, writing some code to make that happen, then writing tests to see if it did happen or not. TDD also has a serious amount of positive side effects, including documentation that will not go out of date, and allowing safe refactoring. But I am not writing to talk about the merits of TDD. I am going to list a few features I like tests to have. None of this is new nor rocket science, but I would like to compile a list of good features for a test suite to have. I am going to get people to comment on this and possibly grow/enhance this list.

1. A good test tells a full story

Most tests fall under a common pattern as below:
SETUP --> EXERCISE --> VERIFY --> TEARDOWN. (as described in ThoughBot's 4-phase-test)
In the setup phase we fabricate a specific state for the system that we are testing. We then perform an action (exercise), then verify the result of that action against our expectations. In the teardown phase we reset the state of the system under test so we have a 'fresh start' for the next test; this is normally handled by the testing framework or can be automated, so there is normally no need to worry about this stage when writing a test, but it is good to be aware of it I think. Ok, example time; I am going to use a very simple domain for this. I want to write a Counter class, which has an #increment method that increases the count, and a #status, which returns the latest count. The counter always starts from zero and can be initialised with a maximum count.
(please ignore the fact that RSpec has a matcher to check for change, which might be a better fit for the test above, as this condenses the exercise and verify phases into one line, which is fine but no good for my point!)
Notice how in object-oriented programming, context is extremely important, so that the same function (in this case #increment) has different outcomes, depending on state. By actively thinking about Setup - Exercise - Verify and formatting our tests accordingly (including empty lines between phases), we are telling a clear and exhaustive story, with no need to go find context from elsewhere. Your future self (or other developers) will thank you for making it so easy to grasp what is happening in your test. A typical anti-pattern to this is to notice that a few tests share the same setup phase and listen to our DRY-reflex, telling us to remove the duplication and have a shared setup phase somewhere. While removing code duplication is most often a good thing, in this case I do not think it is worth sacrificing clarity and context in the individual test. With a setup phase placed away from the test, you are not telling a full story, you are saying: go find this other information somewhere (I don't know where, figure it out!) so you know the context, and then come back.

2. A good test clearly outlines the public interface

What is it that we are testing with our tests? Behaviour. The only reason a system (a class or series of collaborating classes) exists is to provide useful services to the user of that system (either the end user or another sub-system, which ultimately benefits the end-user). So if we are focusing on the end-use of a system, our tests should explicitly be centred around the public interface of the system. The tests should look as a 'menu' of what the system has to offer, so the various methods should be the main headers, with a description of how these behave in different conditions inside. You can then, for a given method, browse through a number of contexts (one indentation), then finally see what you can expect from the system's method in those conditions.

3. A good test provides a clear and effective description

This one seems misleadingly simple but should not be underestimated. It is very similar to choosing effective names for variables, ones that clearly and unambiguously describe what the variable is about/for. If you structure your tests as suggested above in point 2, it will be easier to find an effective description as the method name and context are implicit to where the test is located, so no need to mention them in the description.  See an example description for the Counter class we used for point 1 above. Notice how the test reads nicely in plain English: 'The #increment method, when the counter has reached the maximum count, does not affect the status of the counter'. A good description should be such that the test itself simply translates the description into code, with no surprises.

4. A good test hides irrelevant details

Let's start with an example here. We are going to move away from the Counter example and use a Person class.
